For decades, farmers of color have been discriminated against and left behind—the pandemic has only exacerbated these disparities. My Emergency Relief for Farmers of Color bill helps level the playing field by providing debt relief & building racial equity at the USDA.

We have to make sure that all members of our Armed Forces can serve without fear of violent crime, sexual assault, harassment, and a toxic culture. My colleagues and I are here to get answers.

Fort Hood has the worst rate of violent crime and incidents among all U.S. installations. Last year, nearly 30 servicemembers at Fort Hood died, including eight killed in accidents, six deaths by suicide, five homicides, with six other deaths undetermined.

Fort Hood is where SPC Vanessa Guillen was sexually harassed and murdered. Her death is a horrific loss and reminder of a much larger problem. Following an investigation, 20 soldiers have been relieved or suspended and disciplinary actions are being taken against 11 others.

This week, I’m visiting Fort Hood with a bipartisan group of colleagues from the Armed Services Committee to hear from servicemembers; question base and Army leadership; and inspect Sexual Harassment/Assault Response Program facilities, housing sites, and other areas of concern.

(4/4)

(3/4)

My Amendment directs the Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans’ Employment & Training to carry out a pilot program in at least three states that would help veterans find meaningful employment through short-term fellowship programs.

(2/4)

Chop’s restaurant in Fort Wayne embodies the idea of what a Main Street business should look like. With support from the local Fort Wayne community, Chop’s restaurant quickly adapted to the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic and is now re-opened at full capacity.

Being a business owner, I know what small businesses mean to a local community. Shapiro’s Deli in Indianapolis is a great example of how small business helps build a strong sense of community while complementing a local economy, even through the challenges of COVID-19.

Dougherty Orchards has been run by the family for 6 generations. Agritourism at the orchard has proven to be fruitful for the Dougherty-Solis family business. Family run and community support makes small business the backbone of the American economy. I stopped in August of 2019. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E0j-Zc7WQAIkFxo.jpg

Bandidos Restaurants in Fort Wayne are a staple where they serve. Finding ways to modify service during the pandemic has to be the most crucial part of owning a business. Owner Jimmie Schindler is a great advocate for restauranteurs and I appreciated him hosting a roundtable.

The Ridge Winery combines two essential American professions: agriculture and business. The Ridge Winery is family run and understands the importance of maintaining a foundation in community while operating a business. I visited in the fall of 2019 to hear about the industry. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E0jmum9X0BAbmPd.jpg

Tenzer Hub for Entrepreneurship is a coworking space in downtown Greencastle. Founder Lee Tenzer created a space for entrepreneurs to work while maintaining an office-like environment. I'll have more to say soon but I want folks to know that even in the midst of this health crisis, I believe there's hope on the horizon for those who struggle with mental illness. But we in the Senate have to do the work to help make that vision a reality. 

Time to get to work.

I'm announcing I'm rolling out three bills this month addressing the mental health crisis in America. The theme that unites them all: access to resources. 

When I struggled with depression, resources were there for me. Many Americans don't get those, let's change that.

I'm grateful I got help, but I share this because I want anyone suffering from a mental health issue to know they are not alone. We can all help break the stigma around talking about this.

But also as a Senator, I recognize my unique position. And I want to use it.

Did I live happily ever after? Not quite. Mental illness isn't a box where you're healthy or not—it's a spectrum. 

I struggled again in my 30s as a young mom. But after a few years of treatment, I improved and know I can turn to it if I need it again.

Happier IS possible.

When my roommate first talked to me about how I hadn't been myself, I was in denial. But eventually, I realized it made sense to go see a counselor. I didn't know what to expect and honestly, I was embarrassed. 

But the experience changed my life.

When it started in college, I thought it was just a rough patch. But at some point, it got harder to cope with life's daily challenges. 

Everybody who's wrestled with depression has their metaphor, but many can identify with the sensation of color draining out of the world.

I want to share something personal for Mental Health Awareness month. We need more understanding and help for the millions of Americans who struggle with mental illness.

I'm not saying that just because I'm a Senator, I'm saying that as someone who has suffered from depression.
